greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of cycle-up-down permutations of {1,2,...,n} having no fixed points. A permutation is said to be cycle-up-down if it is a product of up-down cycles. A cycle (b(1), b(2), ...) is said to be up-down if, when written with its smallest element in the first position, it satisfies b(1)<b(2)>b(3)<... .
comment: Hankel transform is A154604. Binomial transform is A000111(n+1). - _Paul Barry_, Apr 11 2011
link: Nathaniel Johnston, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..198
Emeric Deutsch and Sergi Elizalde, Cycle up-down permutations, arXiv:0909.5199 [math.CO], 2009; and also, Australas. J. Combin. 50 (2011), 187-199.
formula: a(n) ~ n! * n * exp(-Pi/2) * 2^(n+3) / Pi^(n+2). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 08 2013
G.f.: conjecture: T(0), where T(k) = 1 - x^2*(k+1)*(k+2)/(x^2*(k+1)*(k+2) - 2*(1-x*k)*(1-x*(k+1))/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 21 2013
maple: g := exp(-z)/(1-sin(z)): gser := series(g, z = 0, 28): seq(factorial(n)*coeff(gser, z, n), n = 0 .. 24);
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Feb 28 2011
